this we get really good coverage for for threats by basically using
threat feeds and so what is a threat feed so just picture this if you can collect a huge amount of malware so
millions and millions of malware samples and you run them through a detonation chamber and you go and you scrape out all the URLs and all of the IP addresses
that you're getting you put those into a big list you've got a pretty good like list of malware that's running on the
Internet you can use lots of other techniques to build those lists but you
know depending on so we'll do that on a daily basis and in fact an hourly basis
in the case of some of our feeds and we'll get the latest threats for kind of
what's bad on the internet at any one point in time and the likewise for the commercial feeds will get both IP addresses and DNS addresses that we'll
use and we'll do comparisons on it so we basically build this big IP reputation service and we run all the traffic
through that it's in the order of like 80 million lookups per second that's like super scaled when we scale this up
that's all using AWS technology underneath so so load balancers and auto scaling groups that sort of thing and
we'll actually do comparisons and so we can get really good detections from this the thing that's nice about this is you
can get really good true positive detections without generating a lot of false positives and false positives are
evil in this space for those of you who've worked in this space before you'll know and when we've talked to a lot of customers about this they say if
you you send us on a wild goose chase to look after detections that aren't really evil then we're wasting a lot of
precious resources there aren't that many great security engineers on the planet and we're gonna turn the service off and so we put a lot of effort into
making sure we keep the rate of false positive super low and this is good for finding things like malware infected
hosts and you'll see if you have a malware infected host the service will pick it up like super fast sites that
are hosting hacker tools so when you go and you pull out a remote access trojan or something like that to launch an
attack or for lateral movement will detect those types of things with this so it's a great catch-all so we wanted
that right away with the service the the real intellectual property behind the service is in the detecting unknown
threats so this is where this is where the real effort is and the real investment so here when you look at it
we use algorithms to detect and behavior we do this in a bunch of ways so first thing we can look at the signal
patterns and so we look at the signal patterns of signature and we could build detections based on that we use
heuristics we use so we use pattern detection we build machine learning classifiers as well machine learning is
really interesting in this space machine learning is terribly good at finding like items it's not so good at finding
anomalous items and so it works really well in some areas where you have a rich data source like cloud trail works super
well and so what we do is we invest in building models for cloud trail we've put a lot of effort into this if you do
this well you can end up getting really good results from it you can get a lot of different detections without writing
like thousands of heuristics or rules we can get really good detections from that and you can detect a lot of unknown
things as well that the problem with it is it super easy to kind of build a classifier that will detect true
positives but really hard to get the false positives out of those models and it requires just a lot of tuning and
validation to do that and so we spend a lot of time doing this so the types of people that we hire tend to be math PhDs
folks who are really strong in data science and you have to go down a dark alley and you have to be willing to do
research so you can go down and resources for three months and think that you might be able to get good detections and at the end it turns out
you can't and you have to start over again so it's a big investment that we have to make this is an area where we
have a lot of expertise at AWS and we're leveraging all of that so we have data scientists on our team but we also have
the AWS deep learning team that we've been working with and they've been great for generating like these great ideas and and we've been working on building
through working through these models just to give you an example of pattern detection or what the data scientist
might do so it starts with visualizing the data and understanding the types of attacks so in this case this is a
brute-force example where you look at packets per flow and if you look at the packets per flow for a brute-force
attack you see this very unique signal pattern that happens this is not low and
slow this is somebody blasting your Linux instance with with with keys and you can see though the packets per flow
goes up substantially and you can see these patterns and so you can work backwards from that and develop
analytics to actually detect those types of patterns and and you have to get really sophisticated with it because
attackers will will try to evade detection and so they'll do low and slow and they'll go slowly and change those
signal patterns and so there's a lot of work to kind of keep up with that I'll talk about that in a moment so let's

modeled after an attack chain and this is an attack chain in the cloud where the attacker tries to compromise an
instance and when they when they compromise the instance the next step is to try to make that pivot to compromise
the account and so they're basically trading credentials that they can get on an instance to try to get account
credentials and do something evil with with the account credentials and so you could you can replace any piece of this
you know these are just phases of the attack you can replace them just as an example recon would be and map scans RDP

remote access Trojan so then get back or a bind shell so we can get back in and from that point we have access back into
the into the host and that's in that point we might try to get the temporary I am credentials off the host so all of
these hosts have temporary I am credentials which which are delivered there and we might want to see what they
do so the first thing I would do if I want to see what they do and I don't want attribution by our security team is
to run them through an anonymizing proxy that's exactly what the bad guys do and so they run them through an anonymizing
proxy they see what the credentials can do when they do that they do reconnaissance and they use signal
patterns and doing that as well and they have an attempt to compromise the the
account if they compromised the account what are the kinds of things that they're looking for well one is exploitation of data and try to get
access to the data that's there but another is just Bitcoin mining on the on the account so if all of a sudden you
see a spike where you have an account that's gone up to its instance limit with the largest instance types that we
have and there's tons of activity there's a good chance that something's wrong there and so we have anomaly detection that'll catch that so if you
look at all phases of this we have detections all around this attack chain so in this case we'll pick up the Recon activity
we'll pick up the fact that hacker tools will pull down for installing the remote access Trojan they went to a blacklist
at IEP the RDP brute-force attack will be there the communication on unusual reports will pick up unusual traffic
volumes particularly over DNS which is not usual and DNS exfiltration itself
will pick up and then the use of yunnan amazing proxy the use of the temporary credentials on a different instance than
they were they were meant for will pick that up as well and then of course the Bitcoin mining at the end of the attack
will pick that up and an unusual instance launched so that's what gives you an idea of the the types of coverage
that we have for the attack chain we have 38 detections that are in the in the service at launch I'll talk about
some of those the categories come in six flavors there's really seven flavors
because there's also a pentesting flavor as well so we do have a special kind of
detection so if you're using a partner product that is actually white listed with our security team and you're just

a known partner product so that we don't kind of scare anybody with it but we want to create visibility there as well
and then these six categories are things like recon a stealth where somebody's
trying to cover their tracks you know recon where they're trying to figure out what's there unauthorized access so so this is the exploitation
phase the cryptocurrency mining all all fits in there so we have all of those
now if you look at the detection flywheels so this is the interesting part of this so for those of you who've
been in the space for a while or know the space really well but most of the intrusion detection services or systems
have been out for years have been high-end services they've they've been very expensive and they go to a limited
number of customers if you're a bad actor it's really hard to get your hands on these and sometimes difficult to see
for a while what they can actually pick up and detach we're kind of turning that on its head so we have a service here
it's low cost we're sending it out across the world it's super easy to access anybody can access it good good
actors bad actors alike and so we're taking a different approach here and so
what we're doing is we're signing up to get on a treadmill and we're gonna be on this treadmill for a long time and we
